title: How to Clean Essential Oil Bottles

steps.headline: Take the bottle apart.
steps.description: By taking the bottle apart, you can make sure that each part of the bottle is completely clean. You want to get rid of any unused oil as well as the smell of the original oil from the bottle, and from all of the bottle's parts. Unscrew the cap or mist spray top and set aside. Remove the plastic ring from around the neck of the bottle, remove it and throw it away. Put other bottle parts you want to clean, such as a dropper or orifice reducer, along with with the cap or top.

steps.headline: Remove the label with your fingers.
steps.description: Find the edge of the label, and using your fingernails, peel it off the bottle. The label may come off smoothly, or it may come off in clumps, leaving glue residue and pieces of the label left stuck on the bottle. Don’t worry about getting it all off with your fingers, as the next step will make removing the leftover label easy.

steps.headline: Pour warm, soapy water into a tub.
steps.description: You’ll be submerging the bottle in this tub first to loosen the remaining bits of the label from its exterior. This will also help remove any glue residue that may remain on the outside of the bottle. You don't need any special kind of soap for this step. Standard dishwashing liquid will work just fine.

steps.headline: Put the bottle in the tub.
steps.description:
You should leave the bottle in the tub for between 10 and 15 minutes. When you remove the bottle:
Peel off the remaining label and glue residue with your fingernails. Apply lemon essential oil to the surface of the bottle to remove the leftover label and glue completely.

steps.headline: Drain the tub.
steps.description: When the tub is empty, rinse it out. Then fill it with fresh warm water. Instead of soap, add a half a capful of a non-toxic cleaner to the water. This mixture is what you'll use to eliminate the residual oil and the smell.

steps.headline: Soak the bottle and other bottle parts in the tub.
steps.description: This time, leave everything in the tub for just 5 to 10 minutes. This will get rid of any remaining oil, as well as the smell of the original oil.

steps.headline: Remove the bottle and bottle parts from the tub.
steps.description: Let everything dry for a couple of hours. When everything is dry, you'll have a clean bottle. Now you can use for your other oils, perfumes, or blends!

steps.headline: Fill a basin with high-proof alcohol.
steps.description:
The basin should be deep enough to fit your entire bottle. Vodka works well for cleaning out essential oil bottles. It works as a solvent, dissolving unused essential oil. Vodka not only works well for cleaning essential oil bottles but also can be used to clean:
Windows and mirrors
Kitchen surfaces
Bathtubs.

steps.headline: Disassemble the bottle.
steps.description:
By taking the bottle apart, you can soak the cap and bottle, as well as any other bottle parts, separately in the basin. This will help you get the whole bottle absolutely clean. First:
Twist off the cap. If there is an orifice reducer cap, pry it out with your fingers. Then place these bottle parts, along with any others that need cleaning, in the basin.

steps.headline: Steep the bottle in alcohol for two to three days.
steps.description: You'll want to reposition the bottle and its parts several times to make sure the alcohol is dissolving all of the leftover oil. The alcohol will also loosen the label on the outside of the bottle.

steps.headline: Remove the bottle and parts from the basin.
steps.description:
Your bottle might be fully clean by this point. But there might still be some leftover oil. To get rid of it:
Scrub out the bottle with a bottle brush. Also, clean the other bottle parts with a cloth.

steps.headline: Peel off the label.
steps.description: If the label hasn't fallen off in the basin yet, it should be extremely loose. Remove any remaining part of the label by slipping a fingernail under an edge and pulling it away from the bottle with your fingers.

methods.name: Removing Residual Oil with Epsom Salt

steps.headline: Take the label off of the bottle.
steps.description:
Lift the edge of the label from the bottle with your fingers, and pull it away from the surface. If you can't get all of it off with your fingers:
Put the bottle in a sink full of soapy water. Take the bottle out after about 10 minutes. Pick the rest of the label off with your fingers again. Dry the bottle completely.

steps.headline: Fill a jar with Epsom salt.
steps.description: The jar should be large enough to fit the pieces of the bottle. It should also be wide enough to fit other bottle parts or additional bottles you want to clean. Make sure you're using unscented Epsom salt. Using unscented Epsom salt lets you transfer the residue and smell of the essential oil from the bottle to the salt. Using scented Epsom salt instead of unscented won't help you clean it. It could make your bottle smell like the scented Epsom salt.

steps.headline: Put the bottle in the jar.
steps.description: Remove the cap from the bottle and place both in the jar. Also, put any other bottle parts, such a dropper, in the jar. Set the jar aside for 24 and 48 hours. Move the jar ever so often so that the salt covers every part of the bottle.

steps.headline: Gather the bottle and bottle parts from the jar.
steps.description: Empty the salt from the bottle back into the jar, then shake the salt residue off of the bottle parts into the jar. The salt should now be infused with the remaining essential oils. The scented Epsom salts can be used in your next bath or saved for another future use.

steps.headline: Immerse the bottle and bottle parts in a container of hot water.
steps.description: The water should be close to boiling. Leave the container alone until the water is cool to the touch. Then take everything out.

steps.headline: Dry the bottle and bottle parts.
steps.description: You can air dry everything on a towel. Or you can rub the bottle and each part vigorously with a paper towel or cloth. Once fully dry, put the bottle back together and use it to store your favorite oils.
